column3: How often do you think that moderation decisions should be publicly posted via an official moderation account? | Local content removal
column4: How often do you think that moderation decisions should be publicly posted via an official moderation account? | Local account limits
column5: How often do you think that moderation decisions should be publicly posted via an official moderation account? | Local account suspensions
column6: How often do you think that moderation decisions should be publicly posted via an official moderation account? | Remote content removal
column7: How often do you think that moderation decisions should be publicly posted via an official moderation account? | Remote account limits
column8: How often do you think that moderation decisions should be publicly posted via an official moderation account? | Remote account suspensions
column9: How often do you think that moderation decisions should be publicly posted via an official moderation account? | Remote instance limits
column10: How often do you think that moderation decisions should be publicly posted via an official moderation account? | Remote instance suspensions
column11: What situations that lead to moderator intervention should be posted about publicly? | Spam and promotional content
column12: What situations that lead to moderator intervention should be posted about publicly? | Hate speech and discriminatory language
column13: What situations that lead to moderator intervention should be posted about publicly? | Violence and threats
column14: What situations that lead to moderator intervention should be posted about publicly? | Personal attacks and harassment
column15: What situations that lead to moderator intervention should be posted about publicly? | Inappropriate or offensive content
column16: What situations that lead to moderator intervention should be posted about publicly? | Copyright infringement
column17: What situations that lead to moderator intervention should be posted about publicly? | False information and misinformation
column18: How much does the number of affected remote users matter with regards to public posting of moderation decisions? For instance, suspending a remote single user instance with a few follows, versus a larger instance with hundreds of connections? We are defining number affected as users with pre-existing follow or follower relationships.
column19: How much does the number of affected local users matter with regards to public posting of moderation decisions? We are defining number affected as users with pre-existing follow or follower relationships.
column20: How timely should moderation announcements be made?
column21: When should local accounts be warned to self-edit their content — prior to content removal should they not comply — based on type of content? This question presumes that the moderation team already agrees that the content should be removed. | Spam and promotional content
column22: When should local accounts be warned to self-edit their content — prior to content removal should they not comply — based on type of content? This question presumes that the moderation team already agrees that the content should be removed. | Hate speech and discriminatory language
column23: When should local accounts be warned to self-edit their content — prior to content removal should they not comply — based on type of content? This question presumes that the moderation team already agrees that the content should be removed. | Violence and threats
column24: When should local accounts be warned to self-edit their content — prior to content removal should they not comply — based on type of content? This question presumes that the moderation team already agrees that the content should be removed. | Personal attacks and harassment
column25: When should local accounts be warned to self-edit their content — prior to content removal should they not comply — based on type of content? This question presumes that the moderation team already agrees that the content should be removed. | Inappropriate or offensive content
column26: When should local accounts be warned to self-edit their content — prior to content removal should they not comply — based on type of content? This question presumes that the moderation team already agrees that the content should be removed. | Copyright infringement
column27: When should local accounts be warned to self-edit their content — prior to content removal should they not comply — based on type of content? This question presumes that the moderation team already agrees that the content should be removed. | False information and misinformation
column28: How important are these ethical considerations when it comes to deciding whether to publicly post moderation decisions? | Respect for user privacy and data security
column29: How important are these ethical considerations when it comes to deciding whether to publicly post moderation decisions? | Fairness and impartiality in moderation decisions
column30: How important are these ethical considerations when it comes to deciding whether to publicly post moderation decisions? | Transparency in moderation policies and practices
column31: How important are these ethical considerations when it comes to deciding whether to publicly post moderation decisions? | Avoiding censorship and bias
column32: How important are these ethical considerations when it comes to deciding whether to publicly post moderation decisions? | Protecting vulnerable users
column33: How important are these ethical considerations when it comes to deciding whether to publicly post moderation decisions? | The potential for continued harm
column34: If a moderation decision is not posted publicly and someone asks about it publicly, when should those decisions be shared?
column35: If a moderation decision is not posted publicly and someone asks about it privately, when should those decisions be shared?
column36: Does the person asking about the moderation decision matter? | If the affected party is asking
column37: Does the person asking about the moderation decision matter? | If a local member is asking
column38: Does the person asking about the moderation decision matter? | If a remote user is asking
column39: Assuming a team of multiple moderators, how important is it to know specific moderators that were involved in moderation decisions?
column40: How much does legal responsibility factor into your desire for moderation transparency?
column41: How detailed should moderation announcements be?
column42: Would aggregated moderation data be useful for transparency? (For instance, number of accounts suspended for spam, number of instances limited, etc)
column43: If a confidential appeal form existed, would you utilize that to appeal moderation decisions? | On behalf of yourself
column44: If a confidential appeal form existed, would you utilize that to appeal moderation decisions? | On behalf of a local member
column45: If a confidential appeal form existed, would you utilize that to appeal moderation decisions? | On behalf of a remote user/instance
column46: Freeform! Is there anything that you'd like to share concerning Moderation Transparency?
column47: How would you identify yourself?
column48: Enter your email address ONLY if you want to be notified directly of updates on survey results.

column46: I can't remember the researcher name, but someone posted research in the last 5 years that showed when you don't specify why a moderation decision was made when dealing with stuff like online extremism, it's more likely to result in that person going to more extremist online locations and being further radicalised. Similar behaviour can be observed in poor behaviour not being sign posted properly during moderation decisions. So, for instance, a lot of subreddits on Reddit these days, will post which sub or site wide rule has been broken when content is removed by subreddit mods.

column41: Announcing accounts/instances/content affected,Announcing reasons for moderation (detailed),Announcing decisions by type (general)
column46:
I think that moderators should have a right to keep a decision confidential (or provide reduced information about it) if providing full (or any) information would be sufficiently disturbing to the instance userbase (i.e. if the average user of the instance would need to reach for the metaphorical "brain bleach" after reading an announcement with the standard level of detail for the instance) - but in this case the affected party should always have a right to full info (and local users should generally have a right to the full info)
If the content is unquestionably illegal in any jurisdiction covering instance administration, moderation, infrastructure, or a significant portion of the userbase, then further restrictions can be applied (e.g. local and remote users may only rarely obtain details on the decision, and receipts cannot be obtained by any party)
Remote users may have a slightly reduced importance in requests for further info relating to any decision compared to local users, bu

column46: This is hard: there are goals of providing the service (e.g. following all relevant laws), protecting its users, avoiding fedidrama/burnout of various moderation teams. It's very likely no optimal compromise can be made with these. There is also the conflict between things needing time to coordinate and calmly specify, while others post in real-time about presumed decisions.

column46:
I think what I'd like to see is updates to the mod account with short, straightforward descriptions of why you had to take action, plus what you did. When relevant, include receipts, redacted or omitted to protect victims' privacy. You don't need to go into detail about why you took action more than "this broke X rule so we have given the user a 12-hour suspension" or "this user/instance/etc puts our users at risk so we are suspending it" or such.

For spam I think you probably can just skip 'em though tbh.


Also re: the question of knowing who made a mod decision, it should never be relevant since y'all are a team.

Moderation is hard, and I appreciate all that you do. I prefer to treat internet communities (even large servers) as "someone's living room" - the mods set the standards for what is and isn't appropriate, and if you don't like it, go elsewhere.

I care much less about impartiality, "rules-based" moderation or other legalistic / formal concerns than I do about being able to understand what's going on any why.

column46:
When should moderators be allowed to use personally identifiable information attached to a user account but not publicly available to contact users from their personal accounts: Under no circumstances. (For more information see https://commission.europa.eu/law/law-topic/data-protection_en)

When should criticism of moderation decisions by local users be removed? Only in case of breach of applicable law, or if instance rules have been seriously breached (Certain rules clearly need to be applied more leniently in these cases, such as rules protecting private conversations. This does not apply to rules forbidding things such as hate speech and doxxing, even if those are not forbidden by applicable law.). Never in order to cover up poor moderation decisions.

column46: While posts can be helpful, a better option I think is a central web page listing accounts limited/suspended and why, along with the date it went into effect. There should be an appeal process for any limit/suspension as well. An appeal process allows for an individual or instance to fix/improve and rejoin the community. It also allows a chance for "sorry I didn't realize blank, I will do better in future". When considering what to post transparency wise in the case of violence/threats, its always good to consider what that will entail for the victim as well as the person limited/suspended. As sad as it is, some people are intentionally trying to get suspended/banned as many places as possible, almost like a badge of honor. There are also times where suspending one can cause others to "dog pile" the victim with the blame. I mod/admin several large matrix chat rooms. Moderation is hard, thank you to all mods!

column19: Number of local users is somewhat important
column41: Announcing accounts/instances/content affected
column46: Moderation should be almost always be limited to users. Most systems have both serverside and as client features ignore lists for accounts and instances on an individual basis. There is little need for instance admins to interfere with user's decisions (not) to block someone. There may be a point in preventing ban evasion by shielding users who blocked someone from a new account when the identity is clearly the same. On the other hand doing so proactive may be a burden for the admins and there should be better spam filter like systems in the hands of users. It is important to respect the autonomy of users because things like instance blocks create catch 22 situations when, for example, choosing an instance and either having to choose one who blocks A for reasons you may not agree with (or even without known reasons) or B, but without an option to have an instance that blocks neither. In general many Fediverse instances err on the side of overblocking what is unfortunate for new users.

column46:
• Not all moderation decisions need be posted publicly if doing so has a high chance of causing additional harm to the local community
• Generally moderation transparency is recommended promptly if the local and near associated community requests so
• Moderation service is to the benefit of the local instance first, the desires of the local community is prioritized over the desires of remote community
• Aggregate moderation decisions that sever remote relationships quarterly or even monthly often are irrelevant, if an instance suspension or limit occurs, and assuming the moderation team will disclose the reasoning/decisions publicly at all, it should be done immediately. Late transparency reports do not help severed users reconnect if the report is published weeks/months later and any delay only adds more difficulty for users to reconnect
• Moderation on remote with incredibly low relationship rates with local users generally need not be disclosed, esp. for spam/botted instances

column46:
so this sylveon admistrates faer own instance, albeit at much much much lower scale than tech.lgbt

fae feels like defederation should avoided when possible when there are any relationships, especially involving local active users following remote users

(of course, that's not to say defederations cannot be done, but there should be a consensus among staff team, and the alternatives need to be considered)

if there is a decision to defederate a popular instance (as far tech.lgbt users are concerned), it definitely makes sense not only to announce the decision, explain the reasons, and give people time to migrate if they choose to

generally vagueness fae feels is to be avoided for defederations of popular instances, in particular because it makes other instances, and in particular the affected instance ask questions about what happened to know what to do (like what happened with nano.lgbt, for instance)

for smaller instances with barely any connections, transparency isn't as necessary

column41: Announcing accounts/instances/content affected,Announcing reasons for moderation (detailed),Announcing decisions by type (general)
column46: Having done moderation work for a few years myself, albeit on a different type of platform, I do have a very good understanding for the wish to just do the job as best one can and not need to constantly be open to public scrutiny, misunderstanding, misinterpretation, and so on. However, I also live for being as open, honest, and truthful as possible - and I firmly believe that being public about moderation decisions is, at the end of the day, something that keeps the platform/community healthy and honest. If one lays out one's actions and the intentions of these actions, readily available for whomever wishes to see, then one might foster more open conversations and achieve deeper understandings between those involved as well as onlookers. Aye, there will inevitably be quarrels and complaints - especially from those unwilling to put the proverbial shoes of others on their own feet - but that would always be the case anyway; only in the instance of closed practice, it'd be sans the good.

column46: I think one of the main times I've wanted slightly more transparency is when trying to figure out why a large, popular instance has been limited. Fosstodon is the one that comes to mind, and with the number of reply guys on there I can take a wild guess why, but it'd be nice to know for sure what tech.lgbt's stance was that caused the instance limit.

column46: Whether, and in how much detail, a moderation decision should be publicly announced and explained feels very context-dependent to me. But I've now had one occasion where an instance was suspended and I was (mildly) affected, and having to rely purely on trust in the moderation team that the suspension was a reasonable course of action was rather unpleasant. So I don't think a 99% non-disclosure policy of moderation actions is the way to go. If a small group of people can in theory radically change how I experience the fediverse, I want them to have some degree of (collective) accountability, even if I personally trust them. Without more transparency, such accountability can't really exist.
